title: Appropriations bill (United States)
summary: In the United States Congress, an appropriations bill is legislation to appropriate[1] federal funds to specific federal government departments, agencies and programs. The money provides funding for operations, personnel, equipment and activities.[2] Regular appropriations bills are passed annually, with the funding they provide covering one fiscal year. The fiscal year is the accounting period of the federal government, which runs from October 1 to September 30 of the following year.[3] Appropriations bills are under the jurisdiction of the United States House Committee on Appropriations and the United States Senate Committee on Appropriations.[2] Both Committees have twelve matching subcommittees, each tasked with working on one of the twelve annual regular appropriations bills.
